div.l: But yite I pray the be nought wrothe for game
Thou sayste full sothe quod Rog̉er be my faithe
But sothe pley is but pley as the Flemmyng seithe
Be thou not wrothe er we departe here
Though that my tale be of an hostelere
But neủer the lesse I wil not telle as yite
But er we departe I wil the quyte
And therwᵗithall they loghe and made chere
And seide his tale as ye shull after here
A prentyse dwelled whilome in oure cite
Of a crafte of vytillers was he
Gayllarde he was as goldefynche in the shawe
Broun̄ as a berye and a ꝓpropre felawe
With lokkes blake and kēmmed fetously
Daunce he couthe wele and prately
That he was cleped perkyn reueloure
He was full of loue and paramoure
As is the hony kome of hony swete
Wele were the wenche that myght hym mete
For when there any ridyng was in chepe
Oute of the shoppe thidder wolde he lepe
Till he hadde all that Sight sene
And daunce wele he nolde nought turne ayein
And gadred hym a meny of his Sorte
To hoppe and Synge and make disporte
And there they setten steven forto mete
To pley at the dice in suche a strete
For in the towne was there no suche prentise
That fairere couthe caste a paire of dice
Then perkyn couthe and therto he was fre
Of his dispence in place of pⁱrivete
That founde his maister wele in his chaffare
For often tyme he founde his boxe all bare
For swiche a prentys reueloure
That haunteth dyce revell or paramoure
His maister shall it in his shoppe a bye
When no parte no parte of the mynstralcye
For thefte and Ryote be comfortable
All can they pley on gytarn or rable
Revell and ryote as in lowe degree
They ben full wrothe all day as ye may se
This Ioly prentise with his maister lede
Till he was nye oute of his prentysehode
